abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Lahore Water Supply Sewerage
            and Drainage Project in Pakistan was accomplished. The
            International Development Association (IDA) accepted the
            risk of dealing with a new institution and maintained its
            role in the long process of institution building, making
            adequate provisions in the project for engineering support
            to WASA with design and construction advice, and for a
            management team to assist in operations and training. The
            Bank was aware of the Water and Sanitation Agency (WASA)
            inherent problems at the time of appraisal, but possibly
            underestimated the effect. Too much faith was given to the
            inputs of engineering consultants to overcome many of these
            problems. This project confirms the importance of adequate
            project preparation. For more effective project execution,
            it might have been appropriate to extend or intensify the
            assistance of external consultants, but then the effect of
            learning by doing may have been less than desired for WASA.
